but first I want to give a brief is no not a brief history of time but a brief history of cloud providers I think that
this is an interesting part because when I look back historically into the context of the world that we were
starting within when kubernetes was getting started one of the most interesting decisions that was made was
a level of deep integration with cloud
and it was really in part I think because it grew out of people who are building cloud but also a realization
that the tools of the time when you looked at the chef's and puppets and salts and Sable's of the world
while they were thinking about cloud a little bit they really weren't thinking
about it in what I would call a native way and the truth is that kubernetes
itself was very much built to be run inside of the cloud it was it wasn't
built to deploy software that might happen to be running on the cloud it was really built to run inside of a cloud
and in fact in early days the the goals
in some way were to make the cloud easier to consume for developers I think
if you look at the earlier cloud API s that existed out there they were very infrastructure oriented
they said things like virtual machine virtual disk virtual network they those
aren't primitives that developers are interested in and so when we look at the
way I think when we took a look at designing the api's in some ways we were actually trying to refactor the cloud
api's that we saw to be things that were more developer centric but it turns out
that when in doing this we actually really kind of assumed the cloud in many
respects and I think that this was the place you know the most interesting place where we first ran into this was
in the networking environment so kubernetes early on made this
interesting decision which was that every single pod in the cluster would
have its own IP address right and in
many places as we design the system we thought hey you know what we need to meet people where they are and in a few
places we made very opinionated decisions this was a very opinionated decision and it basically was horrible
for every on-premise network provider right so in the early days when we were
starting to talk about this - kubernetes people would say oh great in a cloud in Azure or anywhere else it's relatively
easy for you to dynamically say hey I want to add a route I just want for this sit or block I want all the packets to
go to this place but for these physical environments it was actually quite
challenging and and that is why you saw people like core OS starting to design things like flannel which was
really designed to be a network abstraction that could give a cloud like
a good like cloud like routing to physical environments and so in fact in building kubernetes for the cloud we
actually built something that was a little bit hostile to the debt to the physical data center you know fast forward five years and we've both
networking providers have stepped up a little bit but also enough things like flannel have been built and other sorts
of CN eyes have been built that it's a lot easier than it was but I think it's interesting and to look back and actually say that in the view of
integrating with the cloud we actually kind of pushed away the data center and
that's actually you know I think a an important lesson that you no matter where you you sort of build for your
natural biases no matter where those happen to be whether in cloud or not I
think what's also interesting is that kubernetes itself was built by cloud
providers right I think if you look at all of the other examples of software in the orchestration space it was mostly built by people operating
software not necessarily by people providing the cloud and I think that this changes the perspective obviously
you know people like Red Hat brought a lot of energy as well and they're not necessarily a cloud provider but a lot
of the code that came in came from Google and Microsoft and Alibaba and other people who were really building a
cloud and that I think changed the way that the api's were shaped and then I
think also interestingly enough we have sort of flipped around to a point where we're actually mature enough that we're
actually taking back from the cloud and so in the work that we are doing in cake in the gatekeeper project to bring
policy to kubernetes we're actually looking back at things that are being
done in say a j''r policy and looking back at lessons learned around our back
around how do we do network firewalling and applying things that have actually already been built in the cloud and API
is that our customers said hey you know what we miss when we as we go into kubernetes we miss having policy we miss
having you know network network firewalls bringing those we miss having our back I mean
kubernetes was built without our back when it first started these are fundamental characteristics of what it's
needed to be in the cloud let's take and be influenced by the way that they were designed for the cloud and bring it back
into the curb annuities project itself and so interestingly enough not only where the cloud providers building it
but actually the project itself has started to look back at things that were part of you know if we had started out
by saying hey we're gonna change the cloud we've actually now gotten to a place where we're saying ok what are the
things that we should have brought along with us as we as we build forward on top
of the cloud but as as much as kubernetes was built by and for the cloud it turns out actually that the
cloud wasn't built for kubernetes and especially in the early days but
even to today we have seen countless examples of assumptions that we made
around the way that kubernetes works that don't necessarily match with the assumptions that that the cloud
providers made and I think the first place and most obvious place where this happened and you know continues to
happen at times was around disk mounting and unmounting right so kubernetes
assumes hey I'm gonna create a container I'm gonna mount a disk to it I'm gonna delete the container disk is gonna move
no cloud API was built for this right every single cloud VM API was built
around the idea that you you know created a virtual machine you attached a couple of disks and then you let it run
forever right and ever and ever and ever and you weren't constantly ripping disks
on and off of machines this is both in the hypervisor stack as well as honestly in the Linux kernel itself so I don't
remember if people I don't know how many people were out using Linux when USB you
know was just coming in plug and play was just coming in but every single time I plugged a disk or a keyboard or a
mouse into a Linux machine and then removed that plug you gave it a little
silent prayer to the kernel that it wouldn't hang on you right because the the kernel hadn't been built for it
right the kernel hadn't been built for the idea that somebody'd be ripping mice in on and off a computer that somebody be
pushing disks on and off a computer and the same thing was true in the cloud right and so in every cloud provider
we've seen challenges with disk attach and detach and you know honestly of
course with the azure cloud provider we're still optimizing that path right we're still doing work to ensure that
the expectations of kubernetes around how infrastructure is expected to behave match up with the the designs that
people take into account when they're building out that infrastructure I think other put another place is this
similarly for load balancers we've had clouds where load balancers took 20 minutes to create right and creating a
load balancer in 20 minutes is fine if you create it once a year and you never change that load balancer ever again but in a world where services come and
go where you're creating load balancers to do continuous integration tests which is what we were doing at the time it's
just not okay right we there's this expectation around a very very dynamic
API so if if cloud was a little bit dynamic kubernetes was really dynamic
and I think what we've seen over the last five years is that cloud providers themselves have had to step in as no
exception cloud providers have had to step up and improve the way they deliver api's but the good news for the cloud
providers is actually that everyone else is going there too it wasn't just not
just kubernetes that is driving this demand although kubernetes drives a very
significant fraction of all API calls that end up on Asscher and probably on other clouds too it's also actually the
same thing that other people are doing when they're doing continuous delivery systems when they're doing all sorts of other kinds of online activities the
control plane for the cloud is actually no longer really the control plane it's really becoming as essential as the data
plane but as we push forward into cloud providers there is actually even more problems so the next thing we ran into
was that not all clouds look the same like you squinted the clouds and you're like well yeah they pretty much look the
same and then you get into the details and it turns out that for example one of the cloud providers out there it doesn't
give you IP addresses when you create load balancers gives you a cname instead right and you get a DNS name
when the rest of kubernetes had assumed that when you created a load balancer you got an IP address seems like a small
difference but it actually has significant ripple effect in various places if what you were expecting was an
IP address suppose you were programming DNS to do you know suddenly you have to use a cname record instead of an a record in
order to program DNS and again kubernetes has been sold on this notion that like it's portability right it
gives you portability and abstraction above the clouds but the clouds have this way of leaking up and leaking
through into the cloud provider itself another example is things like ipv6 right Cal just gave a great talk about
ipv6 and dual stack support and kubernetes not every cloud provider supports ipv6 Asher does but not every
cloud provider does and I imagine as they do it's going to look a little different here and there and so I think these are the places where you know we
continue to see challenges trying to figure out what where do you draw the abstraction line and how do you say you
know what it's okay that there are these little differences and yet still give people a single unified interface they
can program against disks or another great example right since some places disks can be attached right only our
disks have to be attached exclusively to one machine other places the disk can be attached to read-only to a bunch of
machines that has changes the way people build and lay out their kubernetes clusters so there's all of these
challenges as you start looking at how do I build a helm that can run in every single cloud if there are these
different characteristics depending on the cloud right so these are all places where this notion that you could have a
cloud provider abstraction and just have everything magically work have sort of broken down historically over time then
another the one of the biggest problems that that we've run into lately both in
the azure cloud provider and honestly elsewhere is throttling right every
single we have run users out of API quota on every single cloud provider out
there right and and you know over time I
expect this is this is a recurring theme until the clouds actually become to come
to a place where they can provide effectively infinite capacity right again what you're seeing
in the cloud is that the cloud was built for people using CL eyes to occasionally create resources it wasn't built for
automation pounding against it 24 by 7 and so we're having to change and adapt to the API infrastructure that we build
in Azure in order to be able to support the notion that across the world there's
going to be programs that just wake up every minute and check to make sure that that disk that was attached a minute ago
is still attached to a virtual machine and that's a very different paradigm than what people are used to and it continues to be a challenging one for us
to work through in a variety of different contexts and then finally I'm
there is this problem in kubernetes itself which is that the cloud provider
code is deeply attached to the kubernetes binaries that are built this
means that improvements to the cloud provider like we've built for the Azure cloud provider are tied to kubernetes
releases it means that we have to cherry-pick fixes into an old version of kubernetes in order to make those fixes
available to users on the agile kubernetes service it means that we can't you know do weekly releases we do
a weekly release of aks we do a weekly release to the azure kubernetes service but we can't do a weekly release of our
cloud provider code right so we've been limited in our ability to be agile by
the fact that this design decision was made to deep too tightly couple the kubernetes codebase with a cloud
provider codebase it was the right decision at the time right we favored install simplicity we favored the idea
that you could install one binary and it would all just work we could distribute one binary and it would work we wouldn't
have to distribute a kubernetes binary and an azure binary or a kubernetes binary and a GCP binary we wanted it all
to be together but now as the project is scaled and the demands of updating these this code has changed we've been forced
to consider the consequences of that decision about combining things together and so we're in the process of breaking
things apart and providing for an independent cloud provider as a set binary that can run independent of
kubernetes and that's what ping Fei is going to show in just a second and that is the future of the way that we are
going to be able to deliver updates to the azure cloud provider every single week tied to the releases of the agile
community service itself I think that the most interesting thing the consequences of what we've found is that
in the last five years we've gone from the clouds saying why are you treating
our api's in this way to people actually building features within clouds
specifically around capabilities of kubernetes so you know just as a concrete example we have as your
networking building new features for us to light up private clusters for as recruit for the azure kubernetes service
right so we're getting to a place where supporting kubernetes in Azure is a
first-order requirement for our API teams we have disks we have people
working on storage and disks saying what do we need to do to make disks that are natural for cloud native micro services
what do we need to do to improve attach and detach times and things like that so we've gone through this amazing
transition I think not just in Azure but really in all of the clouds where there's a realization that supporting
these patterns is not something that we do sort of grudgingly but actually something that we do in tight
conjunction in partnership with the teams we've seen a really great partnership develop between the virtual
machines scale sets team and the agile kubernetes service team delivering together solutions for kubernetes that
work well for for our customers and then finally we're actually seeing the cloud
do innovation so recently we announced this service called teleport it's just a
part of the azure container registry which enables you to do 0 pull 0 download image container starts right so
you can actually start up a container nearly instantaneously no matter how big it is because you're no longer forced to
pull an image across the network to get it to a machine before you can start running it right so that's I think a
great example of how we're not just in in our API is but actually innovating in partnership with Azure storage in our
infrastructure to actually change the way that people experience kubernetes and that's something that you know would
have not existed three or four years ago I think the other interesting piece of this is that the cloud is also starting
to build on top of kubernetes so when you look at things like the spring service that was recently announced in
Azure there's a spring boot platform where you can bring a Java app have a spring experience it's built on top of
aks it's assuming kubernetes as a building block on which we're gonna deliver higher level services similarly
with kubernetes at the edge sequel server is saying hey if you want to run a big data version of sequel server if
you want to run sequel server in linux we're going to just assume that you have communities out there and we're gonna
start delivering cloud based services on top of that kubernetes cluster so we're starting to see not just that kubernetes
is being built in conjunction with the cloud but the cloud itself is actually being built up from the kubernetes layer
and that's a trend that is only going to continue as we move forward and then finally as I mentioned kubernetes itself
is being is trying to do a better job building itself in a way that makes
